en.Slide 1: Let's see how we can guess the closed form solution of the recurrence $T(n) = 2T(n/2) + 1$
en.Slide 2.1: For a problem of size $n$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for two subproblems of size $n/2$ each
en.Slide 3.1: For each problem of size $n/2$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for two subproblems of size $n/4$ each
en.Slide 4.1: For each problem of size $n/4$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for two subproblems of size $n/8$
en.Slide 5.1: This pattern will continue till we reach a problem of size $1$ in which we will have $n$ subproblems each of which requires $1$ unit of work
en.Slide 6: Since we have $\log{n + 1}$ levels and the amount of work at each level is a base $2$ exponent, the closed form solution of $T(n) = 2T(n/2) + 1$ can be modeled by the summation $\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{\log{n}}2^i$
en.Slide 7: Since we already know that $\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{\log{n}}2^i = 2n - 1$. Then, we have the closed form solution of $T(n) = 2T(n/2) + 1$ evaluates to $2n - 1$
en.Slide 8: Similarily, we can guess the closed form solution of the recurrence $T(n) = 2T(n/2) + n$
en.Slide 9.1: For a problem of size $n$, we have $n$ units of work plus the amount of work required for two subproblems of size $n/2$ each
en.Slide 10.1: For each problem of size $n/2$, we have $n/2$ units of work plus the amount of work required for two subproblems of size $n/4$ each
en.Slide 11.1: For each problem of size $n/4$, we have $n/4$ units of work plus the amount of work required for two subproblems of size $n/8$
en.Slide 12.1: This pattern will continue till we reach a problem of size $1$ in which we will have $n$ subproblems each of which requires $1$ unit of work
en.Slide 13: Since we have $\log{n + 1}$ levels and the amount of work at each level is $n$, the closed form solution of $T(n) = 2T(n/2) + n$ can be modeled by the summation $\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{\log{n}}n$
en.Slide 14: Simply, $\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{\log{n}}n = n(\log{n} + 1)$. Then, we have the closed form solution of $T(n) = 2T(n/2) + n$ evaluates to $n + n\log{n}$
